conclusion: To find the magnitude of the electric force experienced by the small ball when it reaches point B, we need to consider the electric field due to the two point charges at points M and N.
The charges at points M and N are +Q and -Q, respectively.
The distance from point B to points M and N is L since MNB is an equilateral triangle.
The electric field due to a point charge Q at a distance r is given by: E = kQ/r^2.
For charge +Q at M: E_M = kQ/L^2
For charge -Q at N: E_N = kQ/L^2
The electric field due to +Q at M points away from M.
The electric field due to -Q at N points towards N.
Since MNB is an equilateral triangle, the fields at B due to M and N are at an angle of 60° to each other.
The components of the electric fields along the line connecting M and N cancel out because they are equal and opposite.
The perpendicular components add up: E_resultant = 2(kQ/L^2)cos(30°)
The force on the ball with charge +q in the electric field is: F = qE_resultant
The electric force experienced by the small ball along the horizontal direction is the resultant force F of F_1 and F_2. From the parallelogram rule, we obtain F = 2F_1cos(60°).
